1.q_string: One end of a brass rod \(2 m\) long and \(1 cm\) radius is maintained at \(250^{\circ} C .\) When a steady state is reached, the rate of heat flow across any cross-section is  \(0.5 \;cal\;s^{-1}\). What is the temperature of the other end? (\(k =0.26\; cal \;s ^{-10} C ^{-1} cm ^{-1}\))
A black body has a wavelength \(\lambda\) at a temperature of \(2000 K\). Its corresponding wavelength at a temperature of \(3000 K\) will be:

The thermal conductivity of a brick is \(1.7 W m ^{-1} K ^{-1}\) and that of cement is \(2.9 W m ^{-1} K ^{-1}\). What thickness of cement will have the same insulation as a brick of thickness \(20 cm\)?

Two vessels of different materials are identical in size and wall thickness. They are filled with equal quantities of ice at \(0^{\circ} C\). If the ice melts completely in \(10\) and \(25\) minutes, respectively, then compare the coefficients of thermal conductivity of the materials of the vessels.

A liquid cools from \(60^{\circ} C\) to \(40^{\circ} C\) in \(10\) minutes. What is the temperature of the liquid in the next \(10\) minutes? Given: temperature of the surroundings is \(5^{\circ} C\).

The solar constant, which is the energy arriving per second at Earth from the sun, is \(1400 W m ^{-2}\). Calculate the surface temperature of the sun, given that the sun's radius \(=7 \times 10^{5} km ,\) the distance of the sun from Earth \(=1.5 \times 10^{8} km\) and Stefan's constant \(=5.7 \times\) \(10^{-8} W m ^{-2} K ^{-4}\).

Calculate the energy radiated per second from the filament of an incandescent lamp at \(2000 K\) if the surface area is \(5.0 \times 10^{-5} m ^{2}\) and its relative emittance is \(0.85\). \(\left(\sigma=5.7 \times 10^{-8} W m ^{-2} K ^{-4}\right)\)

A black body at \(1227^{\circ} C\) emits radiation with maximum intensity at a wavelength of \(5000 \mathring A\). If the temperature of the body is increased by \(1000^{\circ} C\), the maximum intensity will be observed at:
Which of the following laws states that \(\lambda_{ m }\) is inversely proportional to absolute temperature, where \(\mathring {A_m}\) is the wavelength at which maximum energy is emitted?
A black body at a temperature \(T\) radiates energy \(E\). If the temperature falls to \(\frac{T}{2}\), then the radiated energy will be:

Two rods of the same material have the same length and area. The heat \(\Delta Q\) flows through them for \(12\) minutes when they are joined side by side. If both the rods are joined in parallel, then the same amount of heat \(\Delta{Q}\) will flow in:

q_option: it will neither bend nor shrink
it will not bend, but shrink
1.q_string: A bimetallic strip consists of metals \(X\) and \(Y\). It is mounted rigidly at the base as shown in the figure given below. Metal \(X\) has a higher coefficient of expansion as compared to that of metal \(Y\). When the bimetallic strip is placed in a cold bath,

If a piece of metal is heated to temperature \(\theta\) and then, allowed to cool in a room which is at temperature \(\theta^{0}\), the graph between the temperature \(T\) of the metal and time \(t\) will be closest to:

Same quantity of ice is filled in each of the two identical metal containers \(P\) and \(Q\) having the same size and shape, but different materials. In \(P\), ice melts completely in time \(t _{1}\) whereas in \(Q\), the time taken is \(t _{2} .\) Then, the ratio of conductivities of \(P\) and \(Q\) is:
Two stars \(A\) and \(B\) radiate maximum energy at wavelengths of \(360\; nm\) and \(480\; nm\), respectively. The ratio of the surface temperatures of \(A\) and \(B\) is:
